AFG.main:
Assistance needs due to armed conflict and frequent natural disasters include food, healthcare, and protection.? With the increase in the number of people internally displaced by conflict and the influx of returnees from Pakistan and Iran in the year 2016, shelter and WASH needs have increased significantly. 9.3 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance.?However, the high level of insecurity constrains access.?

INFORM measures Afghanistan’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 7.8/10. Afghanistan’s hazard is of particular concern, at 8.8/10.?
AFG.latest_developments_past:
30/04: Measles outbreaks are on the rise across the country with 94 outbreaks since January, amounting to 1,639 suspected cases and 57 deaths.?

23/04: Four children died and eight were left in critical condition after receiving improper measles vaccinations in Gizab district, Ghazni province. The incident was a result of the lack of qualified health professionals in the remote areas of the province.?
AFG.latest_developments_upcoming:
Pakistan has extended the deadline for registered Afghan refugees to leave the country to the end of the year 2017.

There is a likelihood for average to above-average precipitation during the remainder of the wet season through May.?

AGO.main:
The El Niño-induced drought experienced throughout 2016 has impacted the food security, nutrition and health needs of 1.2 million people in Angola, particularly in the southern provinces.?

Acute malnutrition is a concern, particularly in Cunene and Cuando Cubango provinces, where rates surpass the emergency threshold of 2%. There is an ongoing cholera outbreak and high malaria prevalence across the country. A lack of proximity to basic services poses an access concern.?? 

INFORM measures Angola’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 4.9/10. Lack of coping capacity is of particular concern at 7/10.?
AGO.latest_developments_upcoming: 23/08: General elections in Angola. ?

BDI.main:
Political instability has crippled Burundi’s economy and driven massive displacement, as populations continue to flee violence carried out by both the government and opposition, and their respective supporters. Deteriorating socioeconomic conditions are driving humanitarian needs for basic health and education services, as well as food, nutrition, and livelihoods support.? An estimate 414,000 people have fled political violence to neighbouring countries since April 2015.? By the end of 2017, it is estimated this figure will exceed 500,000.?

INFORM measures Burundi's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster as high, at 6.3/10. Hazard and exposure as well as lack of coping capacity and vulnerability are all at concerning levels: 6.1/10, 6.4/10 and 6.4/10 respectively.?
BDI.latest_developments_past: 21-24/04: A WFP food convoy carrying aid for 112,000 people that had been blocked at Gisenyi border in Kirundo Northern province by Burundian authorities was sent back to Rwanda on 24 April, for security reasons.?

BEN.main: Benin suffered a Lassa fever outbreak in early 2016. For details, see the Special Reports tab.

BFA.main: Flooding in August 2015 affected over 24,000 people in Burkina Faso. ACAPS Briefing Note on the crisis can be found under Special Reports.

BGD.main:
The influx of Rohingya refugees from Myanmar is reported on in an ACAPS briefing note of January 2017.? This report, along with reports of floods in August 2016 are available in the Special Reports tab of this window.

The country is recovering from flooding in July and August, and was categorised as No Severity in the Global Emergency Overview since the beginning of November. The crisis analysis is no longer updated, but ACAPS continues to monitor Bangladesh on a weekly basis, due to its high underlying vulnerability and frequency of natural disasters.

BIH.main: Bosnia and Herzegovina was affected by flooding in May 2014. For more information, see our Briefing Note.

BOL.main: Bolivia has been facing a worsening drought situation since October 2015. In August 2016, ACAPS produced a Briefing Note with an overview of current needs in the country.

BRA.main: When Zika virus hit Latin America and the Caribbean in 2015, Brazil was most affected , reporting over a million cases by early February 2016. ACAPS' Briefing Note on the epidemic is available under Special Reports.

CAF.main:
Almost half of the population is need of assistance. Conflict has resulted in displacement, targeted killings along communal lines, and human rights abuses. Protection, humanitarian access, and food security are priority needs.. Needs continue to exceed available resources, and delivery of aid is expected to decline because funding remains low. 

INFORM measures CAR's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be extremely high, at 8.4/10. CAR's vulnerability is of particular concern.?
CAF.latest_developments_past:
25/04: 7,000 people have returned to Ngaoundaye, Ouham Pende, a town bordering Chad and Cameroon. They were among 22,000 who fled on 4 April, when an armed group stormed the town.?

24/04:  Since March, over 70% of Bakala's estimated 13,000 population have returned, after having fled the town in December 2016 due to fighting between ex-Seleka factions. Returnees are in need of health, nutrition, WASH, and education assistance.?

CHN.main:
A peak in air pollution in December 2016 impacted millions of people across northeast and central China, see our Briefing Note.

Longtoushan township in Ludian county, Yunnan province, was hit by an earthquare in August 2014. 230,000 people were relocated. For details on the immediate impact, see ACAPS Special Reports.

CIV.main:
Côte d’Ivoire is recovering from more than a decade of violent conflict, and the displaced are slowly beginning to return home. The most pressing issue is food insecurity: 76,000 people are are in need of assistance. A high rate of statelessness is a major protection concern and limits access to livelihoods.?? An estimated 700,000 people living in the country do not have any documented nationality.?

Economic improvements and a reduction in food insecurity point to an improving situation in Côte d’Ivoire. Although ranked as a Situation of Concern in the Global Emergency Overview until June 2016, Côte d’Ivoire is now prioritised as a situation of No Severity. ACAPS continues to monitor Côte d’Ivoire on a weekly basis, but updates are no longer regularly posted. It ranks 4.5 on the INFORM Risk Index.?

CMR.main:
Almost 10% of the population in Cameroon is in need of humanitarian assistance, primarily in Far North, North, Adamaoua, and East regions. Conflict in both Nigeria and CAR has led to displacement of refugees to Cameroon. Boko Haram attacks in the Far North region remain regular, with an apparent spike in April 2017. Needs remain high in Minawao camp, which hosts more than 63,000 refugees 

INFORM considers that the risk of humanitarian crisis varies widely, from very high in the Far North to very low in western areas of the country. Nationally, the risk is 6.2/10. Hazard and exposure risk stands at 6.8, and lack of coping capacity at 6/10. ?

COD.main:
A complex emergency has persisted in DRC for more than 20 years. Conflict is between foreign, self-defence, and other armed groups, and mainly impacting the eastern provinces. Although the security situation has improved slightly since 2013, conflict continues. Access remains volatile in the east, and lack of infrastructure is a general problem across the country. Fighting in insecurity is currently mostly affecting populations in Sud- and Nord-Kivu, Ituri, Tanganyika, and Haut-Katanga provinces.Since mid-August 2016, the security situation in the Kasai region has significantly deteriorated due attacks by Kamuina Nsapu militia, and due to clashes between FARDC and the militia. Health is a priority due to recurrent measles, cholera, and malaria outbreaks, and protection concerns are high. 

A presidential election is due in 2017, and it has been agreed that President Kabila, whose term limit ended in December 2016, will then step down. At least 50 people died in election-related violence in 2016. 

INFORM measures DRC's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 7/10. Lack of coping capacity is of particular concern, at 8/10 as well as vulnerability at 7/10.?
COD.latest_developments_past:
02/05: 19 people died of malnutrition out of 50 recorded cases in Iboko health zone, Bikoro territory, Equateur province during the last two weeks of April. Most of the malnourished cases were reported among Batwa people.?

30/04: Armyworms have been reported in 50 territories (out of 145 territories), affecting over 333,000 hectares of maize crops. ?

26/04: 29 civilians were killed following clashes between Mayi-Mayi Nyatura and FDLR in Masisi.?

24/04: Over 162,000 people are in need of humanitarian assistance in Nord-Kivu, including over 117,000 people in need of health assistance and 152,000 people in need of WASH assistance.?

24/04: Over 46,000 new IDPs have been reported in Haut-Lomami and Haut-Katanga from January to March. Over 76% of these IDPs have fled clashes between Batwa and Luba communities in Tanganyika. ?
COD.latest_developments_upcoming: Tension and violence are increasing in Katanga area because of the delay in the elections. There are concerns that a crisis, similar to the war of late 1990s, which followed the overthrowing of Mobutu, could take place. ?

COL.main:
After five decades of armed violence, the peace deal with the FARC has not put an end to violence, as other armed groups battle for territory that the FARC is in the process of leaving. Forced displacement and landmine contamination are major concerns. In rural communities, armed group activity restricts movement and limits access to basic health services, as well as access to crops, and labour markets, especially in the Pacific region.

Colombia also experiences frequent natural disasters, particularly tropical storms and heavy rains on the Pacific coast.

INFORM measures Colombia's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster for 2017 at 5.4/10. Hazard and exposure as well as vulnerability are a particular concern, at 6.8/10 and 5.8/10. ?
COL.latest_developments_past: 27/04: An ELN attack on an oil pipeline in Norte de Santander resulted in an oil spill, contaminating the water and restricting access to safe water for approximately 4,000 people in El Carmen. Classes were suspended and displacement is reported as people move with their cattle away from the contaminated water.?

DJI.main:
Recurrent and severe droughts over the past two decades have led to a significant deterioration in Djibouti’s humanitarian situation. As a result, the population’s coping capacities have steadily been eroded causing rural to urban migration, which has left many households unable to generate sufficient income to meet basic needs.

The presence of migrants and refugees has created additional pressure on the state’s limited capacity. There has been an influx of refugees from Yemen since the escalation of conflict in March 2015. Additionally, the country hosts long-term Somali, Ethiopian, and Eritrean refugees, as well as Djiboutian returnees from Yemen, and transiting migrants. 

INFORM measures Djibouti’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster in 2017 to be high, at 5.3/10 up from 4.4/10 in 2016. Lack of coping capacity is of concern, at 6.5/10.? Humanitarian needs are severely increasing as refugee camps are overwhelmed with refugees and migrants.

ECU.main:
On 16 April 2016, a 7.8 magnitude earthquake struck west of Ecuador’s northern coast. The earthquake left 350,000 people in need of assistance, killed at least 662 people and injured 4,605.? 

INFORM measures Ecuador's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 4.3/10.? 

By mid-August, Ecuador no longer met the criteria to appear in the Global Emergency Overview. ACAPS continues to monitor the country on a weekly basis, but updates have stopped.
ECU.latest_developments_past: An ACAPS briefing note on the earthquake in Ecuador in April 2016 is available under the Special Reports tab.

EGY.main: Egypt hosts some 120,000 Syrian refugees, and has been covered in a number of reports by ACAPS on the Syria crisis. See Special Reports.

ERI.main:
The Eritrean government severely restricts the access of humanitarian actors inside the country. Very little is known about humanitarian needs: UNICEF estimates that the total affected population is 1.5 million.?UN operations have been restricted to health, water supply and sanitation. An average of 5,000 Eritreans per month are thought to flee the country. Much of the country is affected by recurrent drought, which has been particularly severe over the past year as a result of El Niño.

INFORM measures Eritrea's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be 5.4/10. Eritrea's vulnerability is measured at 4.8/10.

ETH.main:
A state of emergency was declared on 9 October following large-scale anti-government protests, and was extended a further four months on 30 March. The protests started in November 2015, and Ethiopian government forces have killed at least 800 demonstrators in 2016. ? ?

Consecutive, below-average rainy season yields for the Gu (from March to May) and Deyr (October to December) seasons have caused severe drought across northern, eastern, and central Ethiopia.  ? This is leading to high levels of food insecurity, particularly in Afar, in Sitti zone of Somali region, and parts of Amhara, Oromia, and SNNPR. Malnutrition has increased significantly. ? Below-average rainfall is projected for the Belg season, which will affect the drought in the southern and south-eastern parts of the country.  ?

Hosting approximately 830,000 refugees from neighbouring countries, including approximately 366,000 from South Sudan, the majority of Ethiopia’s refugee camps have reached full capacity. Overcrowding, malnutrition, and critical shortfalls in humanitarian aid are of concern. Most refugees have been in protracted displacement, but remain in need of assistance.

INFORM measures Ethiopia's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 6.4/10. Vulnerability is of particular concern, at 6.6/10. ?
ETH.latest_developments_past:
28/04: 116,660 people have been displaced in the Somali region in 2017, due to drought and sporadic conflict. ?

27/04: The National Disaster Risk Management Commission announced that the number of people in need of food assistance has increased to 7.7 million, up from 5.6 million at the beginning of the year. ?

16/04: As of 16 April, there were 26,966 cases of AWD/Cholera and 731 deaths reported across six regions (Amhara, Afar, Oromia, SNNP, Somali, and Tigray) in 2017. 98% of all cases were in Somali region. The WHO elevated the outbreak of AWD/cholera to a grade 3 emergency on 20 April. ?
ETH.latest_developments_upcoming: The United Nations meteorological organization said there is a 50 to 60% chance that the Pacific will experience further strong warming this year, which will impact the highlands of Ethiopia. ?

FJI.main: As a result of TC Winston as well as subsequent flooding, Fiji was ranked as a Situation of Concern in the Global Emergency Overview from February to April 2016. Now prioritised as a situation of No Severity, ACAPS continues to monitor Fiji on a weekly basis, but updates are no longer regularly posted. Fiji ranks 3.2 on the INFORM Risk Index.?

GIN.main:
Humanitarian needs in Guinea spiked in 2014 and 2015, when the Ebola epidemic caused a severe crisis throughout the country.

Guinea's baseline indicators (see Country Profile) provide an insight into the country's vulnerability to crisis. Reports relating to the Ebola epidemic are under Special Reports.

GMB.main:
Over 78,000 people are estimated to be in Crisis (IPC Phase 3) food insecurity - up from 35,000 in IPC Phase 3 in December 2016. This is expected to increase to 111,645 from June to August. Over 336,000 people are in Stressed (IPC Phase 2) food insecurity. The The North Bank, Upper River, and West Coast regions are particularly affected. More than 10,000 children under five are severely malnourished. Food insecurity is due to crop failure, rising food prices, and loss of livelihoods as a result of numerous disasters over the last few years.

Former President Yahya Jammeh, who had been in power for over 22 years, stepped down on 21 January, after a period of instability during which he disputed the result and thousands of people fled to Senegal, in fear of violence. The pre-election period saw unprecedented anti-government protests and clashes with police.

INFORM measures Gambia’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very low, at 3.6/10. Gambia’s vulnerability is of concern, at 5.1/10.

GRC.main: Greece has been the landing-point for hundreds of thousands of people seeking asylum in Europe. ACAPS has produced a number of reports covering the humanitarian needs of migrants and refugees: see the Special Reports tab. For more information, see also the theme page.

GTM.main:
A report on the Northern Triangle from December 2016, on the zika virus in February 2016, and the drought in September 2015 is available in the Special Reports tab of this window. 

Guatemala suffered from drought from 2015- 2016, with over 900,000 people classified as food insecure. This, along with gang-related protection concerns made Guatemala a Situation of Concern in ACAPS' Global Emergency Overview. However, drought effects subsided in the second half of 2016, with only 110,000 classified as food insecure in December 2016. This led to the categorisation of Guatemala as No Severity in the Global Emergency Overview. . The crisis analysis is no longer updated, but ACAPS continues to monitor Bangladesh on a daily basis.

HRV.main:
Croatia is one the route taken by migrants and refugees to reach western Europe. ACAPS reports are available under the Special Reports tab. Our theme page provides provides more information on the topic

In May 2014, Croatia was affected by flooding. For more information, see our Briefing Note in the Special Reports tab.

HTI.main:
Haiti is regularly exposed to natural disasters, including hurricanes, floods, earthquakes, landslides, and droughts. The resilience of the population is extremely low, and the political and economic situation is fragile.

Category 4 Hurricane Matthew struck Haiti on 4 October 2016. More than 750,000 remain in need in the most affected areas of Grand’Anse and Sud. The loss of crops due to the hurricane is likely to affect food security throughout the year for the whole country. ? In addition, 80% of Haiti has been affected by El Niño conditions since the beginning of 2015, and around one million Haitians have been affected by drought. A cholera outbreak has persisted since October 2010.

INFORM measures Haiti's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster at 6.5/10. Hazard and exposure is at 5.4/10. Vulnerability and lack of coping capacity are at alarming levels, with rates of 6.7/10 and 7.5/10. ?
HTI.latest_developments_past: 02/05:  Up to 60, 000 people are in need of immediate humanitarian assistance due to recent heavy rains and flooding in the south of Haiti.?

IDN.main: Indonesia is suffering an El Niño-related drought, which has led to a food crisis in 2016. See our Special Reports tab for ACAPS analysis of the crisis.

IND.main: In November 2015, several days of heavy rainfall in Tamil Nadu led to flash flooding. At least 29,000 people were evacuated; Cuddalore district was particularly affected. Go to the Special Reports tab to find our Briefing Note on the crisis.

IRQ.main:
In 2014, Islamic State (IS) took over significant portions of Iraqi territory, triggering mass displacement and severe humanitarian needs. After a military stalemate throughout much of 2015, government operations to retake territory from IS were stepped up in 2016 and are ongoing in 2017, aggravating displacement and humanitarian needs, particularly in Anbar and Mosul corridors.? Access constraints and human rights violations from all warring parties are of major concern.

Iraq now hosts three million IDPs, one of the largest internally displaced populations in the world.? IDPs and Syrian refugees make up 25% of the population in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq (KR-I).?

INFORM measures Iraq’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 6.9/10. Hazard and exposure as well as lack of coping capacity are of particular concern, at 7.7/10 and 7/10 rates.?
IRQ.latest_developments_past:
01/05:  In total, 317 Iraqi civilians were killed in acts of terrorism, violence, and armed conflict in April, compared to 543 civilians killed in March. In April, 403 civilians were injured - down from 567 civilians injured in March. ?

30/04:  In March, over 120,000 children were newly displaced from western Mosul. ?

JOR.main:
Jordan has the second highest per capita concentration of refugees worldwide. The latest estimates put the number of Syrian refugees at 1.3 million, of which roughly half are registered with UNHCR. ??   In addition, Jordan also hosts significant numbers of refugees from Palestine and Iraq, as well as other countries such as Sudan, Somalia, and Yemen.? ? The increase in population has put pressure on local infrastructure and services. Many refugees and vulnerable Jordanians live in substandard shelter, and have substantial food security, livelihoods, WASH, health, education and protection needs.

In addition to the refugee population inside Jordan, an estimated 85,000 Syrian refugees live in settlements around the Rukban and Hadalat border crossings between Syria and Jordan, referred to as The Berm. The border between the two countries has been closed or subject to very limited access since June 2016, due to a number of attacks by IS and other groups. Refugees at the berm lack access to food, shelter, WASH facilities, drinking water and medical care.?

INFORM measures Jordan's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 3.8/10. Vulnerability is of particular concern, however, at 6/10.?

KEN.main:
Drought was declared a national disaster in February 2017, as the number of people affected by acute food insecurity climbed from 700,000 in February 2016 to 3 million in March 2017. Most affected people are in arid and semi-arid lands, with conditions worst in Kilifi, Lamu, Marsabit, Tana River, and Turkana counties. The drought has deteriorated livestock conditions, water supplies, reduced harvests, and has caused conflict over resources.

Seasonal rainfall from March to May causes flooding, and increases the risk of waterborne diseases. New cholera outbreaks were reported in Tana River county and Dadaab refugee camp in April in addition to a prior outbreak in Lamu county.

Kenya also hosts a large some one of the largest  refugee populations in the world, just above 500,000, including over 300,000 from Somalia.

INFORM measures Kenya’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 6.1/10.?

KHM.main: Cambodia is facing its worst drought in 50 years, with water shortages being experienced in 18 out of the country's 25 provinces. Visit our Special reports section to read our latest briefing note.

LBN.main:
Lebanon has the highest per capita concentration of refugees worldwide, hosting more than 1.5 million Syrian refugees, as well as large populations of Palestinian refugees and Palestinian refugees from Syria. Tensions between host and refugee populations are increasing due to food price hikes, pressure on health and education systems, housing, employment, and legal documentation issues. Tensions between Lebanese authorities and the Joint Palestinian Security Forces have increased due to alleged infiltrations of armed groups in some camps. 

INFORM measures Lebanon’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 5.4/10. Vulnerability is of particular concern, at 6.7/10.?
LBN.latest_developments_past: 01/05: 8,000-12,000 refugees on the move following mass eviction near Rayak Air Base in Bekaa Valley.?

LBR.main:
Humanitarian needs in Liberia spiked in 2014 and 2015, when the Ebola epidemic caused a severe crisis throughout the country.

Liberia's baseline indicators (see Country Profile) provide an insight into the country's vulnerability to crisis.

LBY.main:
Libya’s government is split between three rival centres of power: the Government of National Accord (GNA) and the General National Congress (GNC), based in Tripoli, and the House of Representatives (HoR), based in Tobruk. These governments rely on militias for territorial control: the GNA is supported by a powerful militia coalition from Misrata, while the HoR is allied with the Libyan National Army, led by Khalifa Haftar, a former Gaddafi associate turned opposition figure who returned to Libya during the 2011 uprising. The GNC has lost control of Tripoli since the GNA moved to the city from Tunis in early 2016, but remains associated with some Islamist-leaning militias in the capital. These fight occasionally with groups allied with the GNA.

1.3 million people are in need of some form of humanitarian assisstance as the result of a conflict that has generated shortages of food, fuel, water, medical supplies, and electricity, as well as reduced access to healthcare and public services.? Much of the fighting takes place in urban centres, posing serious security concerns for civilian populations. Humanitarian access is a major concern, since most international NGOs pulled out of the country in 2014.?

INFORM measures Libya's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 6.1/10. Hazard and exposure as well as lack of coping capacity are of particular concern, at 8.4/10 and 6.7/10 respectively.?
LBY.latest_developments_past:
24/04: There were fierce tribal clashes between rival Tebu and Awlad Sulaiman communities in central Sebha, following the Tebu confiscation of an Awlad Sulaiman gas truck.?

24/04: An airstrike on a Tebu-run security headquarters and prison in Sebha killed at least five and injured nine. The LNA, which has ties to the Tuareg community, is suspected to be responsible.?

LKA.main:
Over 350,000 peopl have been affected by flooding – 200,000 have been evacuated to temporary shelters.

Click on "Special Reports" to read our latest briefing note on floods in Sri Lanka.

LSO.main:
Lesotho experienced severe drought due to below-average rainfall and high temperatures during the 2015/2016 El Niño. The weakening rand and increased food prices aggravated the humanitarian crisis.  Until early 2017, around one-quarter of the population was severely food insecure at Crisis (IPC Phase 3) conditions, with many people and services with only limited access to water.

Lesothowas categorised as No Severity in March 2017, as the food security situation improved significantly towards the end of 2016 and is expected to continue to improve in 2017 , with no severity in May 2017. The crisis analysis will no longer be updated, but ACAPS continues to monitor Lesotho on a weekly basis, due to its vulnerability to food insecurity.
LSO.latest_developments_upcoming: FEWSNET predicts Lesotho will not have external food assistance needs in July 2017.

MDG.main:
Severe drought conditions have led to a third consecutive year of below-average food production, particularly in the south. Tsihombe, Ambovombe, and Bekily districts in Androy region are most affected: poor households are facing Crisis (IPC Phase 3) food security outcomes.

In the aftermath of Tropical Cyclone Enawo, which made landfall on the northeastern coast of Madagascar on 7 March, food and health needs have been rising in affected areas,  particularly in Antalaha and Maroantsetra districts.?

INFORM measures Madagascar's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 5/10, compared to 4.9/10 in 2016. Madagascar's vulnerability is of concern, at 4.1/10.? ?
MDG.latest_developments_past:
30/04: Preliminary results of SMART surveys indicate  global acute malnutrition (GAM) rates between 10% and 15% in Beloha and Amboasary districts, in the Grand Sud.?

30/04: Only 41% of people in need received emergency food assistance in cyclone Enawo affected districts in the northeast of the country. This is likely to result in Stressed (IPC Phase 2) food security outcomes until the main harvest in June.?
MDG.latest_developments_upcoming:
A below-average harvest of staple food cassava and sweet potato in July and August is expected. Food stocks will deplete earlier than usual and food access is expected to be significantly constrained by November 2016.

Food insecurity in 2017, in terms of magnitude and severity, is expected to increase as food insecure areas of the south approach the peak of the 2016/17 lean season between January and March 2017.

MKD.main: FYR Macedonia is on the route to western Europe for hundreds of thousands of people who are seeking asylum. ACAPS reports on the humanitarian situation among people in transit can be found under the Special Reports tab.

MLI.main:
Insecurity persists in northern and central Mali. Tensions between two of the signatories of the 2015 peace deal, the Azawad Movement Coalition (CMA) and the Groupe Autodéfense Touareg Imghad et Alliés (GATIA), periodically flare into conflict.  Attacks by Islamist armed groups, who are not part of the peace agreement, increased in 2016. 

Overall, a lack of access to basic social services and the low presence and capacity of public administration drives humanitarian needs. IDPs and refugees have slowly been returning home, but over 45,000 people remain internally displaced as of February 2017, and around 140,000 refugees are still in neighbouring countries as of January 2017.?

INFORM measures Mali's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 6.6/10. Hazard and exposure as well as lack of coping capacity and vulnerability are all at alarming levels, at 6.2/10, 6.8/10 and 6.7/10 respectively.?
MLI.latest_developments_past:
30/04: Nationwide state of emergency extended until 31 October 2017. ? 

28/04: 150,000 children are out of school in central and northern Mali, due to insecurity.  ?

MMR.main:
Protracted armed conflict between ethnic groups and the government means over 525,500 people are in continued need of assistance, primarily in Kachin,  Rakhine states.?? Access to populations in need  in these states is constrained. Several armed groups in these states are still in armed conflict with the government.?

In Rakhine state, discrimination against the Rohingya Muslim minority has caused protracted displacement. IDPs in Rakhine have limited access to services and are confined to camps. Since October 2016, tensions between the Rohingya and the Myanmar Army have escalated and access has deteriorated further.?

INFORM measures Myanmar's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster at 6.7/10. Hazard and exposure, as well as lack of coping capacity, and vulnerability are at 7.5/10, 6/10 and 6.6/10 respectively.?
MMR.latest_developments_past:
22/04: Children in ten villages in Ann township, Rakhine state, are suffering from a diarrhoea outbreak. ?

20/04:  In Kachin and northern Shan states an estimated 46,000 people are living in areas where humanitarian organisations have limited or restricted access. ?

20/04: Almost 170 houses and a high school in two villages of Zalun township, Ayeyawaddy region, have been forced to relocate due to erosion of the banks of the Irrawady river. ?

MNG.main: The dzud - a phenomenon characterised by harsh winter conditions - put around 400,000 people in the northern and western Mongolia at risk of losing livestock and livelihoods in early 2016. See our Briefing Note in the Special Reports tab.

MOZ.main:
2.1 million people were reported acutely food insecure as a result of El Niño-related drought in southern provinces.? The number of food insecure is likely to decrease between May and September 2017 due to the harvests. There are acute water shortages in southern Mozambique, despite heavy rains and floods ongoing since October 2016.?

In October 2015, tensions between Renamo and Frelimo erupted into armed clashes. Central Mozambique is most affected. A two-month truce was declared at the beginning of January, after mediators left the country in December, and renewed in March for other two months.??? There are currently 15,000 IDPs in the country.?About 3,000 Mozambicans were reported in Malawi as of March. About 5,500 are in Zimbabwe.?Politically motivated killings had been on the rise in 2016 and aimed especially at Renamo members.?The number of episodes has declined decisively in 2017 after the truce.

INFORM measures Mozambique’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 6/10. Mozambique’s lack of coping capacity is of particular concern, at 6.7/10.?
MOZ.latest_developments_past: 28/04: Following a favourable cropping season, southern and central areas that were in Crisis (IPC Phase 3) until March have improved to Stressed (IPC Phase 2). However, it is likely that localised poor households, especially in areas impacted by flooding and Cyclone Dineo, are still facing Crisis (IPC Phase 3).?
MOZ.latest_developments_upcoming: From June to September, the majority of households will be benefitting from harvests.The whole country will face Minimal (IPC Phase 1) food insecurity.??

MRT.main:
Mauritania has longstanding food security challenges, and severe levels of food insecurity are currently reported in pockets of the country (IPC Phases 3–5). This has contributed to 120,000 cases of malnutrition as of December 2017, most of which are in the south and eastern parts of the country.?

The number of refugees grew towards the end of 2016 as people fled violence in Mali, but has slowed in early 2017.?

INFORM measures Mauritania's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster in 2017 at 5.7/10. Lack of coping capacity is of particular concern, at 7/10. ?

MWI.main:
Drought has led to the most severe food crisis Malawi has faced in a decade: 6.5 million people (40% of the population) are expected to be food insecure in the November-March lean season. Food prices continue to rise as more households have to purchase food to meet their needs. Typhoid and cholera cases are reported across the country.

INFORM measures Malawi’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 4.8/10. Malawi’s lack of coping capacity is of particular concern at 6.4/10 as well as vulnerability at 6.3/10.?
MWI.latest_developments_upcoming: Improved food security outcomes are expected to continue during the peak lean season. In the absence of humanitarian assistance, areas in central and southern Malawi would experience Crisis (IPC Phase 3) and Emergency (IPC Phase 4) outcomes.?

NAM.main: Namibia was categorised as No Severity in April 2017, as the food security situation improved significantly towards the end of 2016 and is expected to continue to improve in 2017 due to generous rainfalls across the country. The crisis analysis will no longer be updated, but ACAPS continues to monitor Namibia on a weekly basis, due to its vulnerability to food insecurity.

NER.main:
Drought, floods, and epidemics in Niger frequently drive food security, nutrition, and health crises. Compounding this situation, and despite regional military efforts, Boko Haram (BH) attacks impact civilian populations along the Komadougou Yobe River and the shores of Lake Chad. Niger is also a transit country for migrants heading towards Europe. Some of them become stranded around Agadez and need protection assistance. ?

As of 19 November, 1.9 million people are in need in Niger, including 340,000 people in Diffa region.?

INFORM measures Niger's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 7.3/10, up from 5.6/10 in 2016. Niger's lack of coping capacity, measured at 7.8/10 is of particular concern.?
NER.latest_developments_past:
01/05: Between 9 January and 25 April, a total of 164 cases of hepatitis E including 25 deaths (case fatality rate of 15.2%) have been reported in the region. All deaths occurred among pregnant mothers. Five of the six health districts in Diffa region have been affected, with Diffa and N’Guigmi accounting for 96% of all the cases reported.?

01/05: Over 2,100 cases of meningitis, including 120 deaths, were recorded. The districts of Niamey 2 and Madarounfa (in the southern Maradi region) have reached the epidemic level. Nine other districts have reached the alert threshold for meningitis.?

NGA.main:
Violence in the northeast has caused massive displacement and at the same time restricted movement: it has disrupted food supplies, seriously hindered access to basic services, and limited agricultural activities. As of January 2017, it is estimated that 14 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance, 8.5 million of whom are in Adamawa, Borno, and Yobe states. Bauchi (2.8 million people), Gombe (1.4 million), and Taraba (1.3 million) also host high numbers of people in need. ?

In seven years of conflict, over 20,000 people have been killed in Boko Haram-related incidents. People affected by violence in Adamawa, Borno, and Yobe, and neighbouring Bauchi, Taraba, and Gombe states are in urgent need of food, access to health services, protection, and education. Since February 2016, as humanitarian access is increasing, extreme food insecurity and malnutrition conditions have been revealed in Borno state.

INFORM measures Nigeria's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster as 'high', 6.3/10, and its coping capacity index is 6.6/10. ?
NGA.latest_developments_past:
28/04: The National Emergency Management Agency has stated that IDP camps in Borno will not be closed by the planned date of 29 May. ?

03/04: Approximately 24,200 Nigerians from Cameroon and 70 from Chad have returned to Gamboru town, Ngala LGA, in Borno state between 1 March and 3 April. 87% had been displaced in 2014 and 7% were forced to return home. ?

NIC.main: In 2015, 500,000 people in the Central American “Dry Corridor”, covering El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, and Nicaragua, were estimated to be facing severe food insecurity. An El Niño-related dry spell brought a second consecutive year of crop losses. See our Briefing Note in the Special Reports tab.

NPL.main:
On 25 April 2015, at 11:41 local time, an earthquake with of 7.8 magnitude hit Nepal. Its epicentre was 77km northwest of Kathmandu, and 68km east of Pokhara. More than 8,600 people died, 2.8 million were displaced, and in all more than 5 million people were affected by the disaster.

ACAPS supported the reporting of the humanitarian impact of the reponse. Weekly bulletins, thematic reports and district profiles were released and can be found here. Earlier and supplementary ACAPS reports can be found in the Special Reports tab.

PAK.main:
Around 3.2 million people are in need of humanitarian aid in Pakistan.? The security situation remains volatile due to militant attacks in urban centres and military operations against the Taliban in the tribal areas. Around 351,000 people remain displaced within Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and FATA.? Additionally around 1.42 million registered and around one million undocumented Afghans are living in Pakistan.? ?The needs of IDPs and Afghan refugees in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa are of particular concern. 

INFORM measures Pakistan’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 6.6/10. Pakistan’s exposure to hazards is of particular concern, at 9/10.?
PAK.latest_developments_past: 02/05: In Faislabad, 100 cases of chickenpox cases have been reported since March. 16 people have died so far. In one case, death was accelerated by a lack of ventilators. Vaccination against the disease is unavailable and overcrowding is the main factor in its spread.??

PER.main:
Peru is vulnerable to natural disasters. Heavy rains and flooding linked to the El Nino phenomenon has resulted in infrastructure damages, people evacuated and shelter needs countrywide in the past few years.

ACAPS published a report on floods in Peru on 22 March 2017.

PHL.main: The Philippines is at high risk of natural disasters. See the Special Reports tab for ACAPS analysis of recent cyclones and food security issues.

PNG.main: The country continues to recover from drought-related food insecurity, but following significant improvements in food insecurity it was categorised as No Severity in the Global Emergency Overview since 28 March, 2017. The crisis analysis is no longer updated, but ACAPS continues to monitor Papua New Guinea on a weekly basis, due to its underlying vulnerability and susceptibility to natural disasters.

PRK.main:
Humanitarian access remains extremely limited in DPRK, and very little information is available on the humanitarian situation. 18 million people, or 70% of the population, relies on the government's Public Distribution System (PDS) for their staple foods. In January 2017, the PDS provided 400g of barley, maize, rice, or wheat per person per day, which is insufficently diverse for healthy development and provides, even with the highest estimate, a caloric intake that is below basic nourishment requirements. ? ? DPRK is disaster-prone, regularly experiencing intense rain, floods, and droughts

INFORM measures DPRK's risk index as 5.6/10. The country also has poor coping capacity, with an estimated lack of coping capacity index of 6.9/10.  ?

PSE.main:
Ensuring the delivery of essential services including healthcare, food, water, and electricity remain of concern across the Gaza strip and the West Bank due to access restrictions imposed by Israel and neighbouring countries. Needs are particularly acute in Gaza, where around 65,000 Palestinians remain displaced from the 50-day war in 2014. The ongoing blockade continues to severely restrict the delivery of services and the movement of people and goods.

INFORM measures Palestine's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster for 2017 to be at 4.8/10, down from 6.1/10 in 2016. Vulnerability is of particular concern, at 6.3/10.?
PSE.latest_developments_past:
28/04: Four hospitals closed in the Gaza strip due to the ongoing fuel crisis that has resulted in electricity shortages. There are a total of 14 public hospitals in the strip. ?

27/04: All pipelines supplying water to Bardala village in the Jordan Valley of the West Bank were destroyed by Israeli tanks, affecting 3,500 people's access to water.?

RWA.main: Rwanda is impacted by the crisis in Burundi, as it hosts refugees fleeing violence. See the Special Reports tab for more information.

SDN.main: Protracted insurgencies are being waged by armed groups across Darfur, and persistent conflict situations in South Kordofan and Blue Nile cause high levels of insecurity. Darfur has been the scene of conflict for over a decade, while violence in Blue Nile and South Kordofan increased significantly after South Sudan gained independence in 2011.  Humanitarian access to conflict zones is severely restricted and remains so despite efforts of the AU and UN to broker a peace agreement and ensure increased humanitarian access.  Violence, food insecurity, malnutrition, and lack of access to basic services have ca used large-scale internal displacement.  According to INFORM, Sudan is at high risk of being overwhelmed by humanitarian crises and disasters (7/10). Hazard, vulnerability, and a lack of coping capacity are at alarming rates of 7.4/10, 6.6/10, and 7/10
SDN.latest_developments_past:
04/05: Hundreds of refugees from South Sudan are crossing the border into a new camp in South Kordofan. The latest count shows 20,000 people. The local commissioner has requested international humanitarian assistance.?

29/04: Food security situation to deteriorate to Emergency (IPC Phase 4) in May/June in SPLM-N areas of South Kordofan and parts of Jebal Marra.?

23/04: 95,000 South Sudanese refugees arrived in the first three and a half months of 2017.?

23/04: 160,000 people are in need of humanitarian assistance in the Abyei area.?

23/04: Severe water shortages are affecting Sortony and Zamzam camps in North Darfur and camp Otash in Nyala, South Darfur.??

SEN.main:
Livelihoods have been affected by both floods and rainfall deficits in northern and western Senegal. Floods between July and September 2016 directly affected up to 20,000 people, destroying many agricultural stocks and threatening livelihoods. ? ??

Senegal scores 5.1/10 on the INFORM index 2017, a rise from 4.3 last year. ?

SLE.main: Sierra Leone was the subject of a number of ACAPS reports covering the Ebola epidemic in West Africa, see the Special Reports tab. Baseline data can be found in the Country Profile.

SLV.main:
INFORM measures El Salvador's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 3.5/10. Lack of coping capacity is of particular concern, at 4.7/10.?

The country is recovering from drought since 2015, and was categorised as No Severity in the Global Emergency Overview since mid-December. The crisis analysis is no longer updated, but ACAPS continues to monitor El Salvador on a weekly basis, due to its gang violence and underlying vulnerability.

SOM.main:
Drought effects stretching back to 2014 were aggravated by a severe El Niño in 2016, increasing the impact in 2017, including possible famine. More than half the population, some 6 million people, are in need of humanitarian assistance. Drought has affected food and water supplies, leading to a major food security and nutrition crisis as well as a widespread measles and cholera outbreaks across the country. Some 600,000 people have been displaced due to drought  between November 2016 and mid-April 2017, with most joining existing IDP camps. Poor seasonal rainfall in April followed by probable El Niño conditions at the end of 2017 make further deterioration of conditions into 2018 likely.

Famine is possible in 2017 if humanitarian assistance is inadequate – a key concern given access remains extremely limited outside of Somaliland: Lower and Middle Juba regions are particularly inaccessible due to the Al Shabaab insurgency.  The government's control is essentially limited to Mogadishu and surrounding areas, although Al Shabaab attacks in the city persist.

The INFORM index score for risk of humanitarian catastrophe ranks Somalia at 9.2 out of 10, the highest of any country.
SOM.latest_developments_past:
02/05: 1.4 million children are projected to be acutely malnourished this year, an increase of 50 per cent over last year. The figure includes more than 275,000 children who will suffer life-threatening severe acute malnutrition.?

02/05: 40,000 children have been forced to stop attending classes in the country due to drought.?

SRB.main:
A cold wave hit Serbia in January 2017. ACAPS short note can be found here.

Serbia is on the route for refugees and migrants heading to western Europe. ACAPS produced a number of Briefing Notes on the situation as part of a project in 2015–2016.

A report on heavy flooding in the Balkan countries in May 2014 is also available here.

SSD.main:
Since the beginning of 2017, clashes between government and opposition forces are reported in Upper Nile, Jonglei, Central and Eastern Equatoria, and Western Bahr el Ghazal, causing widespread human rights violations, large scale internal displacement and refugee outflow towards Sudan and Uganda. Violence against aid workers has escalated, hampering aid delivery in conflict-affected areas.

Famine was declared in southern parts of Unity state at the end of February, and food security is expected to further deteriorate at the height of the lean season in July. Critical malnutrition levels are reported in Unity, Western Equatoria, Western Bahr el Ghazal, Eastern Equatoria and Jonglei. This is compounded by an ongoing cholera outbreak notably in Lakes and Jonglei. The extended rainy season from April to October is likely to accelerate the spread of the disease. 

INFORM measures South Sudan's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster for 2017 to be extremely high, at 8.8/10, an increase from 8.3/10 in 2016. South Sudan's vulnerability is measured at 9/10.?
SSD.latest_developments_past:
27/04: Since 25 April, at least 40,000 people have fled clashes on the West Bank of the River Nile to Aburoc. This number is expected to reach up to 50,000. Food, access to clean water, health, shelter and basic household items are pressing needs. There is no access to Aburoc. MSF suspended its hospital operations because of insecurity and could not get water trucks in.?
 
25/04: Since 10 April, up to 25,000 people have been displaced from Wau town due to clashes. More than 16,400 new arrivals have sought shelter at the already crowded PoC site adjacent to the town.?
 
23/04: Since the beginning of 2017, over 95,000 South Sudanese refugees have arrived in Sudan. 180,000 new arrivals are expected by the end of the year.?

SVN.main: Slovenia is on the route through the Balkans for people seeking asylum in western Europe. ACAPS reports on the humanitarian situation for migrants and refugees in transit can be found under the Special Reports tab.

SWZ.main:
Poor and erratic rainfall in Swaziland are a result of El Niño and date back to 2014. The country experienced significant reductions in crop production in 2016, a situation that will worsen food security in 2017. 492,454 people require food assistance.?For most of 2016 the five major rivers were flowing below critical environmental sustainability levels. Lubombo and Shiselweni, as well as pockets of Hhohho and Manzini were the worst affected.?

The government of Swaziland declared a national drought disaster in February 2016. The situation is worse than during the 1992 drought.

INFORM evaluates Swaziland's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be moderate at 3.1/10. Swaziland's lack of coping capacity is of particular concern at 5.6/10.
SWZ.latest_developments_upcoming: Rainfall forecasts for the 2016/17 main summer cropping season (October-June) indicate an enhanced chance for normal to above-average rainfall conditions.?

SYR.main:
14.9 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance in Syria, including 6.3 million IDPs.

Conflict has killed over 322,000 people, including 86,000 civilians, and caused large-scale displacement. Protection concerns are widespread. WASH and access to food are high priorities, as well as access to health services. Humanitarian needs in areas under prolonged and ongoing siege are particularly high as access is obstructed.

Clashes are ongoing in Dara, ar Raqqa, Homs, and Hama governorates and Deir-ez-Zor city. After more than a month of decreased clashes between parties involved in the ceasefire, fighting resumed in mid-February between the SAA and opposition armed groups, including the FSA. The Turkish army recently increased activity in Aleppo governorate, targeting both Islamic State and the Kurdish YPG. 

INFORM measures Syria's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 6.9/10. The intensity of highly violent conflict in the country is of particular concern . ?
SYR.latest_developments_past:
02/05: 38 people, including 23 civilians have been killed in an IS attack on a camp for IDPs and Iraqi refugees near the Iraqi border. Fatalities may increase due to serious injuries.?

01/05: MSF suspended operations in Eastern Ghouta, Rural Damascus, following attacks by militias on health facilities it supports remotely. MSF has been providing support to the majority of health facilities in the area.?

01/05: 2,800 people were killed by conflict in April 2017 – roughly the same number as in March and in February 2017.  ?

28/04: More than a dozen hospitals were hit by airstrikes in April 2017, putting seven out of service. The Idlib governorate was the most affected. ? 

25/04: 30,000 people live in the open air, without appropriate shelter, in the Jib al Shaair camp in the ar Raqqa governorate. ?

TCD.main:
Over 4.7 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance in Chad, including nearly 900,000 people expected to be food insecure across the country in June.  The country faces security threats on its periphery, most notably from Boko Haram (BH) since February 2015 in Lac region. Attacks have targeted both military operations and civilians, driving people from their homes. Around 130,000 people are displaced in Lac region. Nigerian refugees have been crossing into Chad since 2014, further adding to large refugee populations from Sudan in the east, and Central African Republic in the south.

Underlying vulnerability and food insecurity is high, particularly in the Sahelian zone to the north of the country.

INFORM measures Chad's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster at 7.76/10, up from 6 in 2016. Hazard and exposureVulnerability as well as lack of coping capacity are of particular concern, at 7.2.4/10 and 8.99/10.? ?
TCD.latest_developments_past: No significant updates this week 03/05. Last updated 21/04.

TJK.main:
715,000 people are in need of food assistance in rural central and eastern parts of the country. Around 43% of Tajik’s GDP is generated through remittances, mostly from Russia. The deteriorating economic situation in Russia and restrictions on the migrant labour market have affected Tajik purchasing power by reducing the frequency and volume of remittances, used by many households to buy food. In addition, Tajikistan relies on food imports to cover needs for cereals, and its weak currency means prices are high.

INFORM measures Tajikistan's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium at 4.4/10.?
TJK.latest_developments_past: No significant updates this week 04/05. Last updated 06/04.

TLS.main: The drought induced by El Niño is reported on in an ACAPS Briefing Note of April 2016. Analysis of the country's preparedness is also available under the Special Reports tab.

TUR.main:
Turkey hosts over 2.9 million Syrian refugees, who are  in need of food and livelihood support, and shelter assistance.

Tensions between government forces and Kurdish separatists escalated in July 2015.  Clashes and bomb attacks occur mostly in the southeast, but occasionally in Istanbul and Ankara. Curfews limit access to affected areas, and hundreds of thousands of people have been internally displaced. Widespread destruction of shelter has been reported.

Tens of thousands of people have been arrested, detained, or dismissed since a failed coup in July 2016. Media freedom and the independence of the judiciary are of concern. The crackdown on pro-Kurdish political parties has escalated. 

INFORM measures Turkey's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 5.0/10. Hazard and exposure is of particular concern, at a 7.8/10 rate.?
TUR.latest_developments_past:
26-29/04: Nearly 13,000 people have been suspended from their employment and 1,000 detained for alleged links with the Gulen movement in two waves of mass arrests. Most of those detained are from the security sector, while the dismissals also target academics and justice officials.??

20-25/04: 15 International Medical Corps staff have been detained foralleged lack of documentation, of whom four international staff were deported back to their country.?

UGA.main:
According to UNHCR, Uganda currently hosts over  898,000 refugees and asylum seekers from neighbouring countries.? Most are from South Sudan, who are arriving at a rate of between 1,000-2,000 a day.  Renewed insecurity in some of these countries, such as South Sudan, DRC and Burundi, brought an increase in arrival rates as of the end of 2015, putting Ugandan services under strain.?

INFORM measures Uganda's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 5.9/10. Lack of coping capacity is of concern, at 6.9/10. ?

UKR.main:
Eastern Ukraine has been in a humanitarian crisis since March 2014, when armed conflict erupted between separatists and Ukrainian armed forces. Separatists now control most of eastern Donetsk region, and a small area of southern Luhansk region. 3.8 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance and more than 2.8 million have been displaced. Protection and health are of particular concern in conflict areas, particularly as a large number of older people are affected. Humanitarian access is constrained: virtually all international aid organisations (all in Donestk) have been banned from non-government areas. ? However, in September 2016 UNHCR’s license to operate in Donetsk and surrounding areas was renewed. ?

INFORM measures Ukraine's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 5.3/10. Hazard exposure rating is also very high at 7/10.?

VEN.main: By February 2016, Venezuela had reported over 4,500 confirmed cases of Zika virus. However, unofficial estimates were thought to be as high as 400,000. ACAPS Briefing Note on the Zika outbreak across Latin America and the Caribbean can be found under the Special Reports tab.

YEM.main:
18.8 million people are in need of humanitarian aid, including 10.3 million people in acute need, after fighting escalated in March 2015.? 

An armed advance on the capital in September 2014 by Houthis from the north triggered a civil war throughout the country. A coalition of Arab states led by Saudi Arabia is supporting the Yemeni government with airstrikes. Activities by southern secessionists Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) and Islamic State (IS) compound the security and political challenges.?

The humanitarian situation is further exacerbated by Yemen’s failing economy. The Central Bank in Yemen is near collapse, putting food imports at risk.?

The Inter-Agency Standing Committee (IASC) declared Yemen a Level 3 emergency in July 2015. INFORM measures Yemen's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster at a very high level of 7.6/10. Hazard and exposure as well as lack of coping capacity and vulnerability are all at alarming levels: 8.2/10, 7.9/10 and 7.8/10 respectively.?
YEM.latest_developments_past: 24/04: 106 civillians have been killed as hostilities intensified over the last month, bringing the total number of verified civilian casualties to over 13,000 including 4,773 deaths. ?

ZMB.main:
As a result of El Niño-related drought in southern provinces, almost one million people were food insecure in Zambia.? The worst affected provinces were Southern, Western, Eastern and Lusaka. Current maize prices are 60% above the five-year average.? 

Good seasonal rainfall has, however, improved crop and livestock conditions and households have started accessing green foods in March 2017. The availability of the green harvest marks the end of the seasonal lean period.?

INFORM measures Zambia's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 4.1/10. Lack of coping capacity and vulnerability of particular concern at 6.1/10 and 5.3/10, respectively.
ZMB.latest_developments_past: 28/04: In most of the country, food security is at Minimal (IPC Phase 1) levels, including in the more vulnerable extreme southwestern and southeastern regions.?

ZWE.main:
Zimbabwe has experienced its driest rainy season in 35 years. The El Niño-induced drought has resulted in a severe and ongoing food security crisis. ? This has been exacerbated by a severe economic crisis.

Popular discontent grew throughout 2016, with increasing anti-government protests. Authorities responded with violent crackdowns. Demonstrations have persisted despite police violence.  ??? 

INFORM measures Zimbabwe’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 4.9/10. Lack of coping capacity is of particular concern, at 5.8/10.?
ZWE.latest_developments_past: 28/04: Between April and May, Crisis (IPC Phase 3) food security outcomes are expected.?
ZWE.latest_developments_upcoming: From June through September, Stressed (IPC Phase 2) outcomes are expected as poor households will still face livelihood protection deficits.?
